text: my brother is an only child is a new
film from Italy
directed by Danielle and Luke FD and it
has something in common with a lot of
other Italian films like the best of
youth three brothers Rocco and his
brothers 1900 in that it uses the
rivalry and also the affection between
two brothers as a lens to look at the
social and political upheavals of Italy
over a long period of its history in
this case it takes place in the 1960s
and early 70s their two brothers man
Rico and Otto their father is a factory
worker in a town not far from Rome and
they live a kind of normal working-class
life but then the 60s come along man
Rico goes into the factory becomes a
communist militant falls in love with
Francesca and he becomes increasingly
caught up in left-wing radicalism of the
time pentomino
meanwhile macho whose kicked out of
seminary where he's been studying to be
a priest who's a more skeptical and more
intellectual you might say nerdier of
the two brothers he's drawn into fascism
and becomes a right-wing militant and
the two of them have their ideological
rivalry that goes along with their
sibling rivalry and that also cuts
against the love and loyalty that they
feel for one another there's some good
performances in the movie and it has
kind of a free open breathless spirit
that has something in common with the
Italian movies that were made in the
late 60s and early 70s by directors like
the young Bertolucci and also Marco Bela
Kia but interesting and lively though my
brother is an only child is there's not
quite enough there it doesn't have
enough of a perspective on the times on
what it meant so I almost feel like if
this movie had been made say in nineteen
anyone it would be a very vital document
of its time but since it wasn't since it
was made almost 40 years later when we
should have learned something and gained
some perspective it seems mainly like a
very sweet and entertaining and touching
exercise in nostalgia
